verses.verse: ((3 Job compareth his knowledge with the experience of his friends.16 The penitent shall be saved, and the hypocrite condemned,20 He prayeth unto God, that he would not handle him rigorously.) ) Lo, mine eye hath seen all this: mine ear hath heard, and understood it.
I know also as much as you know: I am not inferior unto you.

But I will speak to the Almighty, and I desire (For although he knew that God had a justice, which was manifest in his ordinary working and another in his secret counsel, yet he would utter his affection to God, because he was not able to understand the cause why he did thus punish him.) to dispute with God.
For indeed ye forge lies, and all you are (You do not well apply your medicine to the disease.) physicians of no value.
Oh, that you would hold your tongue, that it might be imputed to you for wisdom!
Now hear my disputation, and give ear to the arguments of my lips.

Will ye speak (He condemneth their zeal, which had not knowledge, neither regarded they to comfort him, but always grated on God’s justice, as though it was not evidently seen in Job, except they had undertaken the probation thereof.) wickedly for God’s defense, and talk deceitfully for his cause?
Will ye accept his person? or will ye contend for God?
Is it well that he should seek of you? will you make a lie for him, as one lieth for a man?
He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept any person.
Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his fear fall upon you?
Your (Your fame shall come to nothing.) memories may be compared unto ashes, and your bodies unto bodies of clay.
Hold your tongues in my presence, that I may speak, and let come upon what will.

Wherefore do I (Is not this a manifest sign of mine affliction, and that I do not complain without cause, seeing that I am thus tormented as though I should tear mine own flesh, and put my life in danger?) take my flesh in my teeth, and put my soul in my hand?
Lo, though he slay me, yet will I trust in him, and I will reprove my ways in his sight.
He shall be my salvation also: for the (Whereby he declareth that he is not an hypocrite as they charged him.) hypocrite shall not come before him.
Hear diligently my words, and mark my talk.
Behold now: if I prepare me to judgment, I know that I shall be (That is, cleared and not cast off for my sins, as you reason.) justified.
Who is he that will plead (To prove that God doth thus punish me for my sins.) with me? for if I now hold my tongue, I (If I defend not my cause, every man will condemn me.) die.
But do not these two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
(He showeth what these two things are.) Withdraw thine hand from me, and let not thy fear make me afraid.
Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.

How many are (His pangs thus move him to reason with God, not denying but that he had sinned: but he desired to understand what were his great sins that had deserved such rigor, wherein he offended that he would know a cause of God why he did punish him.) mine iniquities and sins, show me my rebellion and my sin.
Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and takest me for thine enemy?
Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the (Thou punishest me now for the faults that I committed in my youth.) iniquities of my youth.

Thou puttest my feet also in the (Thou makest me thy prisoner, and dost so press me that I cannot stir hand nor foot.) stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths, and makest the print thereof in the (Hebrew, roots.) heels of my feet.
Such a one consumeth like a rotten thing, and as a garment that is moth-eaten.
